subject: RE: [junit] Testing EJBs

messageBody:
> From: Alexander Ananiev [mailto:alexander@...]
>
> The idea is that developers will be able to write the class
> to substitute the container-generated class. You'll be able
> to extend the abstract class and provide all getters and
> setters and setup the data you need. There will be API for
> finders, ejbSelects, etc. So you would not even need the
> database to test it. The goal here is to focus on testing the
> business logic, not the container-generated SQL.

I see. Sounds like a good way to do it!

> I have not seen the official statistics but I suspect that
> the usage of CMP is on the rise. It is supported by all major
> vendors ( can't say the same about JDO ) and for many
> project/organizations that pay big bucks for their app server
> licenses it is all that matter. So in many cases it's not the
> choice of CMP vs. Hibernate vs. JDO but CMP vs. roll your
> own. Naturally, CMP wins in this case.

Yes, I guess everyone's mileage varies. For us, CMP isn't yet portable enough by itself. J2EE guarantess a minimum level of portable features (so far), so you end up needing to leverage vendor-specific CMP enhancements, such as auto-incrementing primary keys (IIRC). But these are dependent on special features or specific databases and deployment descriptors, and pretty soon you need a separate codebase for each vendor.

> http://www.mockejb.org
> EJBs made easy

This is cool. I will check it out!

Thanks,
Scott Stirling
Workscape, Inc.

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Stirling, Scott
>
> > Alexander Ananiev wrote:
> >
> > There is no reason why CMP entity beans can't run outside of the
> > container.
>
> In EJB 2.0, CMPs are abstract classes implemented by the
> app server. How would you test these in any meaningful way?
> Even the SQL is generated in most cases. Who uses CMP anyway? :-)
>
> Scott Stirling
> Workscape, Inc.
